title: Finding the Upside of Managing Stress With AS

content: Living with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is no cakewalk. I've been there. The relentless pain, the exhaustion, and the frustration of having your own body seemingly betray you can take a toll on your mental health. But over time, I've learned to turn those daily struggles into sources of strength. I'm here to share my journey and offer you some valuable insights and tips on how to manage stress when you live with AS.

Every day with AS is a unique dance. Some days, it's a graceful waltz; other days, it's a cha-cha with a limp. I've had my fair share of frustrating moments, especially when I felt like I was letting others down by declining social invitations or struggling to keep up with work demands.

One particular instance stands out. A few months ago, I was invited to a friend's party. The mere thought of socializing while managing my AS symptoms, the stiffness, and the discomfort in my upper back when standing in a group of people was daunting. I'd read a fascinating book called The Upside of Stress by Kelly McGonigal, PhD, and her strategies suddenly clicked.

content_blocks.text: Living with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is no cakewalk. I've been there. The relentless pain, the exhaustion, and the frustration of having your own body seemingly betray you can take a toll on your mental health. But over time, I've learned to turn those daily struggles into sources of strength. I'm here to share my journey and offer you some valuable insights and tips on how to manage stress when you live with AS.

Every day with AS is a unique dance. Some days, it's a graceful waltz; other days, it's a cha-cha with a limp. I've had my fair share of frustrating moments, especially when I felt like I was letting others down by declining social invitations or struggling to keep up with work demands.

One particular instance stands out. A few months ago, I was invited to a friend's party. The mere thought of socializing while managing my AS symptoms, the stiffness, and the discomfort in my upper back when standing in a group of people was daunting. I'd read a fascinating book called The Upside of Stress by Kelly McGonigal, PhD, and her strategies suddenly clicked.

content: In it, McGonigal explores the idea that stress can be a force for good, a revelation that profoundly impacted my approach to life with AS. Here are a few strategies from her book, along with my personal tips, to help you manage stress and turn it to your advantage while living with AS.

One key insight from McGonigal's book is that our body's response to stress isn't always a bad thing. It's a call to action. In my case, AS often gives me signals that it's time to slow down. Instead of viewing these signals as obstacles, I now see them as an opportunity to take better care of myself. So if I feel stiffness creeping in, I don't push through the pain; I embrace it as a cue to take a moment to stretch, breathe, and relax.

McGonigal suggests that you can reframe how you think about stress. Rather than seeing it as a negative force, try to perceive it as your body's way of preparing you for a challenge. When facing a stressful situation with AS, like a busy workday or a social event, I tell myself that the stress response is gearing me up for a performance. This mindset shift has significantly reduced the anxiety I used to feel about these situations.

content: Dealing with AS can be isolating, especially when you're turning down invitations or struggling at work. But remember, you're not alone. One of the key takeaways from McGonigal's book is that social connection can be a powerful antidote to stress. Don't hesitate to confide in friends and family about your condition. They can offer support and understanding, which can be remarkably stress-reducing.

Self-care isn't selfish; it's essential. AS requires that we take better care of ourselves than most. I've made self-care rituals a non-negotiable part of my daily routine. It could be something as simple as a warm bath, a quiet moment with a good book, or a gentle yoga session. These moments not only reduce stress but also serve as opportunities to check in with your body.

Another pearl of wisdom from McGonigal is the importance of setting achievable goals. Understand your limitations, and don't let the fear of letting others down drive you to overextend yourself. Instead, focus on your accomplishments, no matter how small. Celebrate your victories, whether it's completing a work task, attending a social event, or simply getting through a day with less pain.

content: Living with AS can be overwhelming, but you're stronger than you think. With these strategies, you can learn to dance with stress rather than be swept away by it. The path to managing stress with AS is a journey. It's OK to stumble, to seek support, and to embrace your body's signals.

You've got the tools to manage stress now. AS doesn't define you; it's just a part of your story. It's time to flip the script and turn your struggles into strengths. Your life with AS can be fulfilling, even with the challenges. So embrace the upsides of stress, and remember, I’m rooting for you!
Stay connected to others with ankylosing spondylitis. Join our Facebook Support Group now.
